property.propdesc: Tasks are relevant to users when they have to perform that task. Therefore, the logical choice is to write in the present tense.
Include only one procedure per topic. If necessary, tasks can link to other tasks. Smaller, more specific tasks increase reusability.

property.proptype: Write task titles in a present-progressive verb-first form

propdesc.p: To make it easy for readers to identify tasks, their titles should describe what a user does in this task.

property.proptype: Write short descriptions for all task topics
property.propdesc: For easier navigation and consistency, all topics (including tasks) should contain a shortdesc element providing a bit of context on when and why the task should be performed.This should not repeat the title, but instead provide more context.

property.proptype: Begin (non-conditional) cmd commands with an imperative verb
property.propdesc:
Examples:
Run dita-ot-helper
Click File Open
If steps can be performed in any order, use the steps-unordered element instead of steps

property.proptype: Begin conditional commands with the condition
property.propdesc:
Examples:
if no name was previously specified, enter your name
if the application prompts you to grant administrator rights, click Allow

property.proptype: Mark optional tasks using the XML attribute importance
Use the info element to provide additonal information to a step
property.propdesc: This might include descriptions of the command specified in the cmd or some other relevant info.

property.proptype: Use the stepxmp element to provide an example of something that gets performed in a step
property.propdesc: This could, for example, be a sample of how the output should look like:

property.proptype: Use the stepresult element to describe the results of a step, if necessary
property.propdesc: Don't point out the obvious. Results obvious to the target audience, such as Window X opens can be ommited.
